episodes.title: Outrageously Strict Rules Mormon Missionaries Have to Follow
episodes.description:
I would not last a day being a missionary at this point in my life. Sometimes I still have dreams that I am a missionary and they won’t let me go home to see my kids. Bleh. I am so glad my two sons will never have to leave for two years to waste their time on this. 

Resources mentioned/used in this video:
*Manners for Mormon Missionaries Videos:
(https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLpe4KHqzMOV8094j9KflB9140NjtGKTPS&si=pCKKdWtKESo18Eqs)
*Missionaries returning home early:
(https://www.sltrib.com/religion/2018/10/01/commentary-more-mormon/)
*Updated Missionary rules:
(https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/study/manual/missionary-standards-for-disciples-of-jesus-christ/03-missionary-conduct?lang=eng)
*Why I regret my Mormon mission:
(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6uicAn4l9z4&t=18s)

(https://www.sltrib.com/religion/2019/06/27/serving-mission-lds/)
*Rules for missionary supply funds (pre-paid debit card):
(https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/tools/help/missionary-support-cards?lang=eng)

episodes.title: Mormon Afterlife Explained (A Flowchart for your Soul)
episodes.description:
PDS Debt is offering a free debt analysis. It only takes thirty seconds. Get yours at https://PDSDebt.com/alyssa.

An afterlife so complex you have to rely on a flowchart to explain it? Polygamy in heaven? A veil of forgetfulness? Getting your own planet? I cover it all and more in this episode all about the Mormon afterlife. 

My research for today’s episode has also inspired me to start a band called “Sons of Perdition.” Our first album will be titled “Outer Darkness” and the hit single off the album will be “Lucifer’s Groupies.” I am searching for a drummer, bassist, and clarinet player. DM with inquiries.

episodes.title: Joseph Smith: Founding a Church for Power and Sex (Part Two)
episodes.description:
This episode covers Joseph Smith’s life from about 1829 through 1833. Each page I turn, I have some new realization about how little I know about this man. Don’t forget to subscribe to receive the next installment of this series on the life of Joseph Smith! 

Many links below are Wikipedia links. Please keep in mind Wikipedia is a website that summarizes information and links to primary sources. I suggest clicking through to as many primary sources as possible after reading a cursory summary of these topics.

*Part One of this series on Joseph Smith: (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CWDt3-Rovlw&t=645s)
*Rough Stone Rolling by Richard Bushman, the biography written with a faithful interpretation of events: (https://www.amazon.com/Joseph-Smith-Rough-Stone-Rolling/dp/1400077532)
*No Man Knows My History by Fawn Brodie,the biography written with a skeptical interpretation of events: (https://shorturl.at/mnsyU)

episodes.title: ExMormon Reacts to South Park's "All About Mormons"
episodes.description:
Please tell me how South Park teaches us more about Joseph Smith than Mormonism taught us about Joseph Smith. 🧠  You can tell the creators of South Park have a special place in their hearts for Mormons. 

A note, the clips I included are short to comply with fair use laws! I suggest watching the whole South Park Episode FIRST (linked below) and then coming back here to see the reaction :)

episodes.title: Joseph Smith: Fabricated “First Visions” (Part One)
episodes.description:
The disagreement is not typically so much about the events as much as the interpretation of events. 

*Did Joseph Smith make up the first vision? Did he hold it sacred for over a decade? 
*Did the Lord prepare for the 116 lost pages of The Book of Mormon? Did Joseph Smith panic when the pages were lost because he knew he would not be able to reproduce them?
*Was Joseph Smith’s treasure digging an honest way to earn a wage, and evidence he was being prepared by the Lord to accept the angel Moroni? Was it an early sign he was good at spinning lies to convince people to give him money and power? 

These are the questions I investigate here, but ultimately it is up for you to decide.  


Many links below are Wikipedia links. Please keep in mind Wikipedia is a website that summarizes information and links to primary sources. I suggest clicking through to as many primary sources as possible after reading a cursory summary of these topics.

*Rough Stone Rolling by Richard Bushman, the biography written with a faithful interpretation of events: (https://www.amazon.com/Joseph-Smith-Rough-Stone-Rolling/dp/1400077532)
*No Man Knows My History by Fawn Brodie,the biography written with a skeptical interpretation of events: (https://shorturl.at/mnsyU)
*Mormon movie about the life of Joseph Smith: (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1xVw6PsSinI&t=1148s)
*Wikipedia page about Joseph Smith: (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Smith)
*Wikipedia page about the first vision: (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Vision)
*Wikipedia page about Joseph Smith’s run-ins with the law: (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Smith_and_the_criminal_justice_system)
*Wikipedia page about Archaeology and The Book of Mormon: (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archaeology_and_the_Book_of_Mormon#Further_reading)
*Wikipedia page about Reformed Egyptian: (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reformed_Egyptian)
*Wikipedia page about Martin Harris
*Church Website summarizing Joseph Smith’s 1826 Treasure Digging Trial: (https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/study/history/topics/joseph-smiths-1826-trial?lang=eng)
*Church Website summarizing Joseph Smith’s Treasure Seeking: (https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/study/history/topics/treasure-seeking?lang=eng)

episodes.title: Every Rule I Followed as a Mormon (Coffee Can Keep You Out of Heaven)
episodes.description:
Mormon God cares about all the wrong things. He has a lot to share about modesty for women and why coffee is bad, but so little to say about homelessness, disease, poverty, racism, bigotry, and countless other harmful realities. 

Like and subscribe if you liked this video! Next week my video will be about how Mormonism got started, all with a teenage boy named Joseph Smith. This story is honestly WILD and the reality is quite different from what I learned as a faithful Mormon in Sunday School.

A few resources I mention in the video:
*Link to the comprehensive rules list: (https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.mormonsspeak.com/2019/09/04/613-rules-for-members-of-the-church-of-jesus-christ-of-latter-day-saints/&sa=D&source=docs&ust=1712888120371135&usg=AOvVaw3Mzg_231w7gN2qC9jRw5EA)

episodes.title: I Found an Interview with MORMON ME (My Reaction)
episodes.description:
Who is this woman? Is that me? I don't even recognize myself. 

Clarification! I spoke with Carissa and I remembered the story incorrectly. She shared that she was arrested for harassment because she threw a small amount of lemonade at a former friend who was ended up dating her husband right after the got divorced. 

A few resources I mention in the video:
*Link to the original video interview: (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ubXjNG5tybc&list=PLo6WmFbBTUex7r-bg047RIASyrB8IfVdD)
*My book, How to Leave the Mormon Church: An Exmormon's Guide for Rebuilding After Religion (https://www.amazon.com/How-Leave-Mormon-Church-Rebuilding/dp/B0CRS4DF2H)

episodes.title: Secret Mormon Temple Ceremony Explained (What’s With the Green Apron?)
episodes.description:
The Mormon Temple Endowment is a sacred and central aspect of the religious practices within The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church). It is a ritual that takes place in LDS temples and is considered a deeply spiritual and symbolic experience for members of the faith. It is often criticized though for the strange cult-like aspects of the ceremony. Most members are completely surprised by this experience when going through the ceremony for the first time. 

The endowment ceremony is designed to provide participants with knowledge, blessings, and covenants that are believed to be essential for their spiritual journey. It is seen as a step toward achieving exaltation, which is the highest level of glory and eternal life in the Mormon theology.

The endowment is typically administered to adult members of the LDS Church as they prepare for specific milestones in their lives, such as serving as a full-time missionary, getting married in the temple, or simply seeking a deeper connection with their faith. The ceremony involves a series of instructional and symbolic elements that are intended to teach participants about the purpose of life, the plan of salvation, and the eternal nature of God's love.

The endowment ceremony is highly symbolic, and participants go through a series of ordinances, including the washing and anointing, receiving a temple garment, and participating in various symbolic gestures and rituals. These elements are meant to convey spiritual truths, emphasize the importance of obedience, and instill a sense of sacred responsibility among participants. The ceremony has become somewhat more palatable overtime. Members complaints of the more radical aspects of the ceremony have caused the church to change the ceremony overtime.

It's important to note that the endowment ceremony has undergone changes over the years, with adjustments made to certain aspects to reflect evolving understandings and sensitivities. The LDS Church continues to emphasize the sacred and personal nature of the endowment experience, encouraging members to approach it with reverence and a sincere desire to draw closer to God.

episodes.title: Mormon Garments Explained
episodes.description:
Mormon garments, commonly referred to as temple garments or simply "garments," are special undergarments worn by adult members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church) who have received the endowment ceremony in one of the LDS temples. These garments are considered to be a sacred and symbolic reminder of the covenants and commitments made during the temple ceremony.

Here are key aspects of Mormon garments:

Purpose and Symbolism:

Garments are worn as a symbolic expression of the covenants made in the temple during the endowment ceremony. They are seen as a constant reminder of the individual's commitment to live according to the principles and teachings of the LDS Church.
The garment is often referred to as the "garment of the holy priesthood" and is believed to have a spiritual significance, providing protection and a constant connection to one's faith.
Design:

Garments are typically white and made of lightweight, breathable fabric.
The design includes a top and bottom piece, covering the wearer's shoulders, chest, and legs. The garments are meant to be worn under regular clothing.
They may have various symbols sewn into them, such as lines representing the navel and the knee, serving as reminders of one's commitment to obey the commandments and follow the path of righteousness.

When Worn:

Members who have participated in the temple endowment wear these garments throughout their lives. It is common for members to wear them day and night, only removing them for activities like swimming, sports, or intimate relations.

Protection and Blessings:

Many members believe that wearing temple garments brings spiritual protection and blessings. The garments are seen as a physical and spiritual shield against temptation and harm.
Some members share personal experiences attributing protection or guidance to their faithful wearing of the garments.

Personal Choice and Commitment:

Wearing temple garments is a personal choice, and members choose to wear them as a sign of their commitment to their faith and the covenants made in the temple.
Members often express a deep sense of personal significance and spirituality associated with wearing these garments.


Transcript of the LDS Endowment Ceremony
http://www.ldslearning.org/lds-mormon-temple-endowment-ceremony-text.pdf
